facts.text: In March 1968, the Hoshiarpur Local Authorities Constituency was called upon to elect one member to the Punjab Legislative Council.

Election calendar: last date for filing nomination papers -- 12-3-1968; date of scrutiny -- 13-3-1968; last date for withdrawal -- 16-3-1968; date of polling -- 7-4-1968; date of counting and declaration -- 8-4-1968.
Five candidates contested: the appellant and the respondents.
On April 8, 1968, the returning officer declared the appellant successful as he secured one vote more than the 1st respondent.

Kundan Singh (1st respondent) filed Election Petition No. 1 of 1968 challenging the declaration, alleging vote of Hari Singh void as his name included in electoral roll on April 5, 1968 (two days before polling).

Appellant filed recriminatory petition alleging: vote of Tarsem Singh void as he became government servant by polling time; votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh void as names included after last nomination date.
Election petition tried before Mahajan J., who referred question on Hari Singh's vote to Full Bench.
Full Bench by majority held Hari Singh's vote void as name included after last nomination date.
Mahajan J. held votes of Hari Singh, Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh void; recounted valid votes and declared 1st respondent elected.
On scrutiny, one of Harjinder Singh or Balwant Singh gave first preference to appellant.
Tarsem Singh's name in electoral roll but became government servant after inclusion.

legal_issues.text: True effect of sub-s. (3) of s. 23 of the Representation of People Act, 1950, prohibiting inclusion of name in electoral roll after last date for nominations and before completion of election.
Whether votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh could be excluded despite not challenged by 1st respondent.
Whether vote void if application for inclusion before nomination date but inclusion after.
Whether Tarsem Singh disqualified from voting as government servant after roll inclusion.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred; view of majority Full Bench on s.23(3) of 1950 Act incorrect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto overruled impliedly

petitioner_arguments.text: As 1st respondent did not challenge votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh, trial court could not exclude vote in appellant's favour by one of them.
Only votes where electors applied for inclusion after nomination date void; person who voted for appellant applied before, so inclusion after does not void vote.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramswaroap Prasad Yadav v. Jagat Kishore Prasad Narain Singh (Patna HC)

petitioner_arguments.text: Tarsem Singh's vote invalid as he became government servant by polling, disqualified under relevant provisions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.62 Representation of People Act 1951; s.16 1950 Act

respondent_arguments.text: Vote of Hari Singh void as name included after last nomination date.

court_reasoning.text: In view of Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto, majority Full Bench correct: s.23(3) 1950 Act makes such votes void.
Votes of Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh rejected under s.23(3); election petition and recriminatory petition part of one enquiry; must exclude void votes regardless of who challenged.
s.23(3) prohibits inclusion after prescribed date whether application before or after; Patna decision inapplicable as pre-amendment.
Tarsem Singh entitled to vote: name in roll as on nomination date; no disqualification under s.16 1950 Act; s.62(1) 1951 Act; electoral roll final per M. Ramaswamy; cannot go outside Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to vote statutory; entries final.

holdings.text: Votes void if names included in electoral roll after last nomination date per s.23(3) 1950 Act.
Void votes excluded from count even if not challenged by opponent in joint enquiry.
s.23(3) applies regardless of application timing.
Elector with name in roll entitled unless disqualified under Act; roll final.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baidyanath Panliar v. Sitaram Mahto and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of s.23(3) 1950 Act; votes void if included after nomination date.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramswaroap Prasad Yadav v. Jagat Kishore Prasad Narain Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Ratio no application; rendered before s.23(3) amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. Ramaswamy v. B.M. Krishnamurthy and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Finality of electoral roll cannot be challenged in election validity proceedings.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal provision; right to vote based on electoral roll entry unless disqualified.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits inclusion after nomination date; disqualifications; finality of rolls; no civil court jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld declaring 1st respondent duly elected after excluding void votes of Hari Singh, Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh; Tarsem Singh's vote valid.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of 1st respondent as elected upheld.

key_quotes.text: Evidently under an erroneous impression that Harjinder Singh and Balwant Singh had voted against him, the appellant had contended in his recriminatory petition that their votes were invalid.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains basis for rejecting appellant's contention on unchallenged votes.

key_quotes.text: The mandate of that provision is plain and unambiguous. It prohibits inclusion of any name in the electoral roll after the prescribed date whether the application for inclusion was made before or after that date.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The entries found in the electoral roll are final and they are not open to challenge either before a civil court or before a tribunal which considers the validity of any election.
key_quotes.speaker: court
